member.name: T:ActiveUp.WebControls.ITF14Encoder
member.summary: An encoder for ITF14 barcodes, used to encode GTIN numbers in a standardized manner.
member.remarks: The ITF14 encoder sets up the module width and rendering flags of the underlying Interleaved 2of5 generator. These should not be changed.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.ITF14Encoder.Text
member.summary: Gets or sets the data to be encoded.

remarks.para: ITF14 can only encode 13 digit strings, beginning with a mode indicator digit as defined in the EAN/UCC specification, and ending with a 7, 11, or 12 digit number, corresponding to the EAN/UCC-8, UCC-12, and EAN/UCC-13 numbers, respectively, without their check digits. The space between the mode indicator and the 7, 11, or 12 digit number must be filled with zeros so that the total length is 13. (That is, five zeros for a EAN/UCC-8 number, one zero for a UCC-12 number, and no zeros for an EAN/UCC-13 number). The check digit is calculated by the encoder, as it might be different from the original check digit in the EAN/UCC number.

The mode indicator is a single digit, 0-9. To encode standard UCC-12 or EAN/UCC-13 numbers as ITF14, use mode 0. To convert an EAN/UCC-8, UCC-12, or EAN/UCC-13 number to EAN/UCC-14, use 1-8 (the actual digit to use is assigned by the EAN/UCC). Mode indicator 9 is used to encode variable measure trade items. For more information, check the EAN/UCC specifications.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.ITF14Encoder.StandardSize
member.summary: Gets the size that will produce a barcode of the standardized size, 1.25 inches tall.

member.name: T:ActiveUp.WebControls.MSIChecksum
member.summary: The checksumming mode for the MSI encoder to use.

remarks.para: The mod-10 checksum is calculated by separating the number to be encoded into two numbers, consisting of the digits in odd positions and the digits in even positions (for instance, "12345" becomes "135" and "24"). The number containing the rightmost digit is multiplied by two, and the digits from this number and the number containing the second-rightmost digit. (135 becomes 270, and the digits are added: 2+7+0+2+4=15.) The check digit is this number subtracted from the next highest multiple of 10.

The mod-11 checksum is calculated by weighting the digits of the number to be encoded, starting with a weight of 2 at the rightmost digit, and increasing by 1 for each digit to the left. Once the weight goes over 7, it is reset back to 2, so the 7th digit will have a weight of 2, the 8th, a weight of 3, etc. The weighted digits are summed, and the check digit is this value mod 11.

member.name: F:ActiveUp.WebControls.MSIChecksum.None
member.summary: No checksum is appended.

member.name: F:ActiveUp.WebControls.MSIChecksum.Mod10
member.summary: A mod-10 checksum digit is added.

member.name: F:ActiveUp.WebControls.MSIChecksum.Mod11
member.summary: A mod-11 checksum digit is added.

member.name: F:ActiveUp.WebControls.MSIChecksum.Mod1010
member.summary: A mod-10 checksum digit is added, followed by a second mod-10 checksum digit.

member.name: F:ActiveUp.WebControls.MSIChecksum.Mod1110
member.summary: A mod-11 checksum digit is added, followed by a mod-10 checksum digit.

member.summary: Gets or sets the current DPI (dots-per-inch) of the barcode.
member.value: The current DPI (dots-per-inch) of the barcode.
member.remarks:
This value represents the DPI that the barcode will be printed at. This value defaults to zero, which represents "logical" mode. In "logical" mode, the generated barcode represents the relative sizing and positioning of barcode elements, but they are not necessarily in the proper size for printing.
If the value is greater than zero, the barcode generator will generate a barcode using the specified DPI.
member.exception: The value specified was less than zero.

member.summary: The height of all items added to the barcode.
member.value: The height of all items added to the barcode, in pixels.

remarks.para: For MSI barcodes, the only extra height comes from the text at the bottom of the barcode.
This property is meant to be used to generate a desired barcode height. To calculate the height of the size to pass to , multiply the desired height (in inches) by the DPI, and add this number to it.
This property's value is potentially impacted by the value of . The barcode render mode flags should be set before using this value.

member.name: T:ActiveUp.WebControls.PostnetEncoder
member.summary: An encoder for Postnet barcodes.
member.remarks: Postnet is used by the US Postal Service to encode ZIP codes and destination codes. It can encode digit sequences of exactly 5, 9, or 11 digits (not including check digit). The barcode includes a check digit which may be precalculated and appended before it is passed to the encoder; this check digit will be verified by the encoder. It has strictly defined dimensional requirements.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.PostnetEncoder.Text
member.summary: Gets or sets the data to be encoded into Postnet.
member.value: The string to be encoded, or null.
member.remarks: Postnet encodes 5, 9, or 11 digit ZIP codes and delivery codes. The encoder will accept strings of 5, 9, or 11 digits, and will automatically calculate and append the check digit. The encoder will also accept strings of 6, 10, and 12 digits, if the check digit is already known. The encoder will check this digit, and throw an exception if it is invalid.
member.exception: The specified string was not null, did not have a valid number of digits, was not composed of digits 0-9, or included an invalid check digit. The property will be "Length", "Digit", or "Check", respectively, depending on the error.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.PostnetEncoder.Flags
member.summary: Gets flags that represent the encoder's capabilities.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.PostnetEncoder.TextSymbols
member.summary: Gets the symbols that can be encoded.
member.remarks: The encoder can only encode digits. If any non-digit symbol is passed to the encoder, it will fail.

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.PostnetEncoder.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.remarks: Pplanet is used by the US Postal Service to encode tracking codes. It can encode digit sequences of exactly 11 or 13 digits (not including check digit). The barcode includes a check digit which may be precalculated and appended before it is passed to the encoder; this check digit will be verified by the encoder. It has strictly defined dimensional requirements.

The encoder will also accept strings of 12 or 14 digits, if the check digit is already known. The encoder will check this digit, and throw an exception if it is invalid.
member.exception: The specified string was not null, did not have a valid number of digits, was not composed of digits 0-9, or included an invalid check digit. The property will be "Length", "Digit", or "Check", respectively, depending on the error.

member.summary: Gets or sets the dots-per-inch (DPI) of the barcode.
member.value: The current DPI of the barcode, or zero for "logical mode".
member.remarks: If the DPI is set to zero, the generator operates in "logical mode," which produces barcodes with bars of the proper relative size and positioning, but not suitable for printing. If the barcodes are to be printed, the DPI must be set. Due to the strict nature of the dimensional requirements, the barcode cannot be rendered at certain DPIs. If the barcode cannot be rendered at the specified DPI, it will throw an exception when that DPI is set.
member.exception: The specified DPI is less than zero, or the barcode cannot be rendered properly at the specified DPI.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.Calendar.Format
member.summary: Gets or sets the format to use to render the selectors.
member.remarks:
You can specify the display layout using the format specifiers like "hour" or "month".
Fields must be separated by ; (semicolon) char. Non reconized fields are send to the HtmlTextWriter as literal text.
Here are some examples ([ and ] represent a selector:
"month;/;day;/;year" will display
[MONTH]/[DAY]/[YEAR].
"hour;:;minute" will display
[HOUR]:[MINUTE].
"Date : ;day;/;month;/;year; Time : ;hour;:;minute;:;second" will display
Date : [DAY]/[MONTH]/[YEAR] Time : [HOUR]:[MINUTE]:[SECOND].
Format SpecifierName
dayThe day part (1 to 31).
monthThe month part (1 to 12).
yearThe year part (variable).
hourThe hour part (0 to 23).
minuteThe minute part (0 to 59).
secondThe second part (0 to 59).
millisecondThe millisecond part (0 to 999).
other literalRendered as literal text.

member.remarks: Setting a high value to or setting a low value in can produce performance problem. For each year, more than 20 bytes are added to the browser HTML output. By setting this property to true, you can prevent from exception throws without having to set very high maximum year or very low minimum year. If the maximum year value is less than the actual date year value, the maximum year will be adjusted to the actual date year. Same for the minimum year.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.Calendar.WeekNumberFactor
member.summary: Gets or sets the factor used to increase or decrease the week number.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.Calendar.UseSelectors
member.summary: Gets or sets the value indicating if you want to use selectors to select all the date elements.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.Calendar.ScriptDirectory
member.summary: Gets or sets the relative or absolute path to the directory where the API javascript file is.
member.remarks: If the value of this property is string.Empty, the external file script is not used and the API is rendered in the page together with the control render.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.Calendar.UseTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the value indicating if you want to allow time selecting in the calendar.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.Calendar.Months
member.summary: Gets or sets the month names.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.Calendar.SetMonthNames
member.summary: Sets the month names.
member.remarks:
This array of string contains the month names. You can set your own month names to match with your culture. If your website is in french, you will prefer use Fvrier in replacment of February. By default, the months are in english. If the property is set to true, numbers will replace month names.
// Please verify that MonthNamesDisabled property is not set to true <AU:ActiveCalendar runat="server" id="MyCalendar" SetMonthNames="Janvier,Février,Mars,Avril,Mai,Juin,Juillet,Août,Septembre,Octobre,Novembre,Décembre"></AU:ActiveDateTime>

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.Calendar.Days
member.summary: Gets or sets the day names.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.Calendar.SetDayNames
member.summary: Sets the day names.
member.remarks:
This array of string contains the day names. You can set your own day names to match with your culture. If your website is in french, you will prefer use LUN (Lundi) in replacment of MON (Monday). By default, the days are in english. If the property is set to true, the day names will not be displayed.
// Please verify that DayNamesDisabled property is not set to true <AU:ActiveCalendar runat="server" id="MyCalendar" SetDayNames="DIM,LUN,MAR,MER,JEU,VEN,SAM"></AU:ActiveDateTime>

member.summary: Gets or sets the text to use for the confirmation box.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.ExtendedButton.NavigateUrl
member.summary: Gets or sets the URL to use for the button.
member.remarks: If this property is left empty, the standard behavior of the button is to do a postback. However if you specify a valid link, any server-side events will be ignored and the specified link (page) will be accessed just like a standard HTML hyperlink.

member.summary: Gets or sets the currency symbol or code.
member.remarks: If you want to enable the currency auto format, just specify a symbol like $ or a code like USD in this property.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.NumericTextBox.NumericType
member.summary: Gets or sets the numeric CLR type.
member.remarks: This property can be used to set automatically the maximum and minimum values depending of the type. For exemple if you need to have an Int32, you will have to specify NumericType.Int32 and the control will automatically set -2147483648 as the minimum value and 2147483647 as the maximum value. Please note that this features is only available for byte and int data types. For Double and Decimal, you have to enter the maximum and minimum value manually using the string representation of the data.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.PagedControl.PanelCssClass
member.summary: Gets or sets the Cascading Style Sheet name of the panel where the status is displayed.
member.remarks: This property will affect the table line (TR) of the control that display both the info panel and navigation panel. To apply borders or other styles, use the property.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.PagedControl.CellPadding
member.summary: Gets or sets the cell padding value of the table that contain the pager panels.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.PagedControl.CellSpacing
member.summary: Gets or sets the cell spacing value of the table that contain the page panels.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.PagedControl.InfoTemplate
member.summary: Gets or sets the navigation template of the pager.
member.remarks: The default value of this property is Total Records: $RECORDCOUNT$ - Page: $CURRENTPAGE$ of $PAGECOUNT$.
member.example: This property allows your to specify exactly what you want to display in the information panel. The value of this property consist of a string containing both literal and tag content. To display the record count, you must include $RECORDCOUNT$. The available tags are : $RECORDCOUNT$ : display the total number of records contained in the list. $CURRENTPAGE$ : display the current selected page in the list. $PAGECOUNT$ : display the total number of pages contained in the list. $CURRENTINDEX$ : display the current index. Example "Page $CURRENTPAGE$/$PAGECOUNT$. $RECORDCOUNT$ records found." ... will display something like ... Page 2/23. 237 records found.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.PagedControl.InfoTemplateNoRecords
member.summary: Gets or sets the info template used no records is available. If left empty InfoTemplate property will be used instead.
member.remarks: You can use the same tags as .

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.PagedControl.NavigationTemplate
member.summary: Gets or sets the information template of the pager.
member.remarks: The default value of this property is "$PREVIOUSPAGE$" + NavSeparator + "$FIRSTPAGE$ $PAGEGROUP$ $LASTPAGE$" + NavSeparator + "$NEXTPAGE$". The NavSeparator is obsolete but still used in the contructor to assure backward compatibility.
member.example:
This property allows your to specify exactly what you want to display in the navigation panel.
The value of this property consist of a string containing both literal and tag content. To display the record count, you must include $PREVIOUSPAGE$.
The available tags are :
$PAGESIZES$ : display the page sizes selector.
$PREVIOUSPAGE$ : display the previous page link.
$NEXTPAGE$ : display the next page link.
$FIRSTPAGE$ : display the first page link.
$LASTPAGE$ : display the last page link.
$PAGEGROUP$ : display the page group.
$PAGESELECTOR$ : display the page selector (goto).
Example
$PREVIOUSPAGE$ - $PAGEGROUG$ - $NEXTPAGE$
... will display something like ...
Prev. [1 2 3 4 5] Next

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.PagedControl.NavigationTemplateNoRecords
member.summary: Gets or sets the navigation template used no records is available. If left empty NavigationTemplate property will be used instead.
member.remarks: You can use the same tags as .

In this case, just tell your end-users to press SHIFT-ENTER to add a BR (line feed) tag instead of a P (paragraph). When in this mode, you can insert an hard return by pressing CTRL-M. You can also change the behavior while editing by pressing CTRL-K.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.Editor.Template
member.summary: Gets or sets the template or layout to use for the toolbars.
member.remarks:
This method is commonly used to quickly set the tools you need. This is the fastest method to set the template that will be used by the control to automaticelly generate his toolbars and tools collections.
If you set the property to true, this property will be used, even if you add tools later programmaticaly.
If you want to customize the tools, you can access them by their name or index trough the Tools collection of the Toolbars contained in the collection. In this case, don't forget to call before to ensure that the tools are created.
If you want to create customized tools, it's possible to add yourself the Tools.Custom object in the objects contained by the control. You can also develop your own tool objects that require postback handling and more. To achieve this, use ToolBase.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.Editor.MaxLength
member.summary: Gets and sets max characters allowed in the editor.
member.remarks:
The default value is 0 and mean no limit.
You need to know that the max lenght is approximative. It's due to the fact that when the content is typed or pasted, the client-side function will crop the code, then the IFRAME object will try to reformat the HTML code to ensure that the output is valid. I all cases, this will add closing tags, so depending of the size of your document, the max length can be very approximative.

member.remarks: Inserting new paragraphs on RETURN can be usefull. In this case, just tell your end-users to press SHIFT-ENTER to add a BR tard instead of a P. When in this mode, you can insert an hard return by pressing CTRL-M. You can also change the behavior while editing by pressing CTRL-K.

member.name: T:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode
member.summary: The HtmlNode is the base for all objects that may appear in HTML. Currently, this implemention only supports HtmlText and HtmlElement node types.

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode.#ctor
member.summary: This constructor is used by the subclasses.

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode.ToString
member.summary: This will render the node as it would appear in HTML.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode.Parent
member.summary: This will return the parent of this node, or null if there is none.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode.Next
member.summary: This will return the next sibling node. If this is the last one, it will return null.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode.Previous
member.summary: This will return the previous sibling node. If this is the first one, it will return null.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode.FirstChild
member.summary: This will return the first child node. If there are no children, this will return null.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode.LastChild
member.summary: This will return the last child node. If there are no children, this will return null.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode.Index
member.summary: This will return the index position within the parent's nodes that this one resides. If this is not in a collection, this will return -1.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode.IsRoot
member.summary: This will return true if this is a root node (has no parent).

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode.IsChild
member.summary: This will return true if this is a child node (has a parent).

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode.IsDescendentOf(ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode)
member.summary: This will return true if the node passed is a descendent of this node.
member.param: The node that might be the parent or grandparent (etc.)
member.returns: True if this node is a descendent of the one passed in.

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode.IsAncestorOf(ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode)
member.summary: This will return true if the node passed is one of the children or grandchildren of this node.
member.param: The node that might be a child.
member.returns: True if this node is an ancestor of the one specified.

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode.GetCommonAncestor(ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode)
member.summary: This will return the ancstor that is common to this node and the one specified.
member.param: The possible node that is relative
member.returns: The common ancestor, or null if there is none

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode.Remove
member.summary: This will remove this node and all child nodes from the tree. If this is a root node, this operation will do nothing.

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode.SetParent(ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlElement)
member.summary: Internal method to maintain the identity of the parent node.
member.param: The parent node of this one

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode.HTML
member.summary: This will return the full HTML to represent this node (and all child nodes).

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode.XHTML
member.summary: This will return the full XHTML to represent this node (and all child nodes)

member.name: T:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNodeCollection
member.summary: This object represents a collection of HtmlNodes, which can be either HtmlText or HtmlElement objects. The order in which the nodes occur directly corresponds to the order in which they appear in the original HTML document.

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNodeCollection.#ctor(ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlElement)
member.summary: A collection is usually associated with a parent node (an HtmlElement, actually) but you can pass null to implement an abstracted collection.
member.param: The parent element, or null if it is not appropriate

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNodeCollection.Add(ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode)
member.summary: This will add a node to the collection.

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNodeCollection.IndexOf(ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode)
member.summary: This is used to identify the index of this node as it appears in the collection.
member.returns: The index of the node, or -1 if it is not in this collection

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNodeCollection.Insert(System.Int32,ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNode)
member.summary: This will insert a node at the given position

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNodeCollection.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: This property allows you to change the node at a particular position in the collection.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNodeCollection.Item(System.String)
member.summary: This allows you to directly access the first element in this colleciton with the given name. If the node does not exist, this will return null.

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNodeCollection.FindByName(System.String)
member.summary: This will search though this collection of nodes for all elements with the specified name. If you want to search the subnodes recursively, you should pass True as the parameter in searchChildren. This search is guaranteed to return nodes in the order in which they are found in the document.
member.param: The name of the element to find
member.returns: A collection of all the nodes that macth.

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNodeCollection.FindByName(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: This will search though this collection of nodes for all elements with the specified name. If you want to search the subnodes recursively, you should pass True as the parameter in searchChildren. This search is guaranteed to return nodes in the order in which they are found in the document.
member.param: The name of the element to find
True if you want to search sub-nodes, False to only search this collection.
member.returns: A collection of all the nodes that macth.

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNodeCollection.FindByAttributeName(System.String)
member.summary: This will search though this collection of nodes for all elements with the an attribute with the given name.
member.returns: A collection of all the nodes that macth.

member.param: The name of the attribute to find

member.returns: A collection of all the nodes that macth.

member.name: T:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlParser
member.summary:
This is the main HTML parser class. I recommend you don't play around too much in here as it's a little fiddly.
Bascially, this class will build a tree containing HtmlNode elements.

member.name: T:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlParser.ParseStatus
member.summary: Internal FSM to represent the state of the parser

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlParser.#ctor
member.summary: This constructs a new parser. Even though this object is currently stateless, in the future, parameters coping for tollerance and SGML (etc.) will be passed.

member.name: P:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlParser.RemoveEmptyElementText
member.summary: The default mechanism will extract a pure DOM tree, which will contain many text nodes containing just whitespace (carriage returns etc.) However, with normal parsing, these are useless and only serve to complicate matters. Therefore, this option exists to automatically remove those empty text nodes.

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlParser.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: This will parse a string containing HTML and will produce a domain tree.
member.returns: A tree representing the elements

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlParser.FindTagOpenNodeIndex(ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlNodeCollection,System.String)
member.summary: This will find the corresponding opening tag for the named one. This is identified as the most recently read node with the same name, but with no child nodes.
member.returns: The index of the opening tag, or -1 if it was not found

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlParser.RemoveWhitespace(System.String)
member.summary: This will remove redundant whitespace from the string

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlParser.RemoveComments(System.String)
member.summary: This will remove all HTML comments from the input string. This will not remove comment markers from inside tag attribute values.
member.returns: HTML containing no comments

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlParser.RemoveSGMLComments(System.String)
member.summary: This will remove all HTML comments from the input string. This will not remove comment markers from inside tag attribute values.
member.returns: HTML containing no comments

member.name: M:ActiveUp.WebControls.HtmlParser.PreprocessScript(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: This will encode the scripts within the page so they get passed through the parser properly. This is due to some people using comments protect the script and others who don't. It also takes care of issues where the script itself has HTML comments in (in strings, for example).
member.returns: The HTML with the scripts marked up differently
